TopicTitle: Kerbal Space Program 1.0 Enters Experimental Testing

Articles.Content:
> 
> It doesn't matter really. We'll go through the same process, only it'll be post-release and via Reddit.

Right? Time to get a Reddit account, I suppose...

Any word on how this release will handle mods? I'm assuming it'll break lots of things as usual, but one thing about the game that's concerned me for a while is that while mods really make a good game a great game, they severely make it buggy and crash happy as hell. Will Squad improve things on this front? I don't know enough about programming and the innards of KSP/Unity to know if there's anything at all they can do to make modding more robust.

> 
> Again, what was suggested is that the QA / experimentals team took some of its lead from an open testing process - effectively making it parallel and getting best of both worlds.
> The argument was then made that it would take too much time, but I argued that it was overstating it as you're only really using the crowd-sourcing to highlight the common issues.
> 
> It doesn't matter really. We'll go through the same process, only it'll be post-release and via Reddit.

Dude.

What you want was *proven* to be detrimental to the feedback process when the game was smaller, and the fanbase was smaller.

It's not going to work on this bigger scale either.

And aside from the feedback, you know there is going to be a massive influx of completely, utterly useless "Why would you release this update when it's just going to crash all the time?\*" Underlined sections are key. People are idiots. This too was proven when experimentals were public, where a massive amount of people couldn't be arsed to read about the "release" being an unstable test release and cried bloody murder.

You can be as passive-aggressive as you like about this, but it's not changing for the simple reason that what you want won't work (efficiently).

And yes. After the release, some bugs will pop up. But those are the few that slipped through the net. As opposed to all the game crashers, system breakers and save wipers that ARE caught. And those were caught because Squad and the testers didn't have to sift through the ....ton of useless vomit the average user is going dump into the bug tracker.

Okay. Thanks.

My 45 minutes is ticking.

All I ask is that before we get to 1.0 Squad fix the memory leak in OSX that at present is giving me about 10mins of game time before it all locks up and forces a reset. I can load up Activity monitor and watch KSP grab ever increasing amounts of memory until at about 2.4Gb, the whole thing just beachballs. All worked fine up til the current BETA. I even transferred everything onto a new iMac.

Unless this gets sorted I'm outta here. I can't cope with the mess that is 0.9. To be honest, no bug fix release before we go to 1.0 is looking more and more like they've given up and just want to get it released rather than crafting a quality product. 

I've enjoyed KSP since 0.17 or 0.18 but the last couple of releases have been way below par as far as improving existing problems, more a case of adding new features to paper over the cracks. Increasingly frustrated and disappointed.

There might be a solution to my problem but if I can't sort it out how are the people buying a "finished" release game going to find it?

So, this is just my ignorant opinion on the whole subject, but I suspect that the whole race to 1.0 has more to do with meeting retail commitments that were likely set sometime last year than it does them being zapped by one of EA's orbital satellites and turned into clueless idiots who don't understand how to do software development.

It would explain the bizarre polling of the current player base asking what Squad should prioritize for 1.0 release\* while switching from an agile-style project management system of negotiating deadlines (I assume they SCRUM) to a fixed production-based release deadline. I'd love to see the day out of days for each feature to see if Squad's predictions were even close to actual production times... maybe Maxmaps and Jesus (if he's still there) could do a postmortem squadcast for those of us interested in Squad's process.

As for QA, I think Ted has done a good job laying out the process for us, and the fact that Squad has allocated additional time for the expressed purpose of bug killing and testing would suggest that Squad is aware of our concerns and have taken appropriate measures to address them. Further speculation regarding QA strikes me as being both unproductive and, quite frankly, unwarranted.

IMHO, we should put our torches in a dry place and wait until 1.0 has been released to see whether or not we need to form an angry mob to storm Squad Castle and poke Ted with our pitchforks.![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

\* to my trained PC/PM eye, this is actually an alarming sign that indicates serious project mismanagement, but considering Squad's consistent PR blunders despite their clever marketing skills, it doesn't surprise me that there is systemic dysfunction throughout the organization that they'll need to address at some point

> 
> All I ask is that before we get to 1.0 Squad fix the memory leak in OSX ...

*Maybe they can't.* Maybe none of them know what it causing it, and therefore how to fix it. In which case, the only way to fix it would be to revert to before 0.9 for ever -- and how popular would *that* be?

* * *

I am perfectly certain that they will be working on it.

One technique used by devteams is to allocate such an issue to a subset of the test-team and get them to test the hell out of the problem, using specially-crafted builds that report extra data. It takes time and careful effort, not least because Special Test Builds quite often *don't* show the weird bug that is being tested for.

(Adding any extra code can interfere with buggy code causing it to appear to work. Not that this in itself ever helps to identify the root cause of the bug. The programmer can usually explain it *once he has tracked down the bug*, never before.)

At least this sort of testing can go on in parallel to other development and testing, so the game progresses while the hard work of testing the bug goes on.

That's what debugging amounts to sometimes. It's a tough job, and it's not made easier by impatient clients who never understand this. This situation won't change until somebody creates an AI that can debug code automagically -- at which point somebody (probably Google) will invest in a billion worth of servers programmed with this AI and every other programmer will be out of a job. For ever. (Or maybe clients will learn to be patient, pigs will fly and we'll all become immortal and move to the Big Rock Candy Mountains!)

> 
> *Maybe they can't.* Maybe none of them know what it causing it, and therefore how to fix it. In which case, the only way to fix it would be to revert to before 0.9 for ever -- and how popular would *that* be?

Then they should delay 1.0 release indefinitely until they fix it.

However, as has already been said, they seem to have already fixed it so this discussion is moot.
Don't release it yet! I need to uninstall my mods, delete some crafts, remove some saves, and buy a hype train ticket!

@Scoundrel

I think you've hit on the root of the problem. I've been suspecting the same thing for some time, that Squad is being driven by behind the scenes contracts with deadlines that were likely poorly chosen either due to overconfidence on the part of the devs, pressure from management, or likely a combination of both. A large part of the reason for so much of the community being up in arms about this whole thing comes from those PR blunders you mentioned, starting with the Curse thing Squad has basically sidelined the community for important decisions that affect everyone (especially the game's community) and the decision to go for 1.0 (even if it was based on earlier deadlines) is more of the same. It was a decision that was made behind closed doors and Squad still hasn't really done anything to clear up the FUD around this whole issue, and their relative silence on this whole thing is what keeps feeding the speculation.

I'm sure that the QA team is doing the absolute best they can, that was never really the issue. I agree that sometimes the criticism of Squad has gotten a little out of hand, but many times it still is valid criticism. Stopping the criticism won't change anything, Squad will continue exactly what they're doing. If we keep the criticism at an appropriate level and to the point, focusing on specific issues instead of just a generic hate on Squad (and encourage Squad where appropriate, like their decision to hold off on Unity 5 until it's more stable), we may still be able to encourage them to change their course, even just a little, like the recent announcement that they've dedicated extra time to testing (which is a very good decision).

At this point, I think the best thing Squad can do is to release a post on all relevant channels (the forums, reddit, twitter, etc) on the state of the game. They need to be honest with the community and provide details, if there are retail commitments behind the deadlines, say so. An apology to the community for not being upfront on the state of everything (the devnotes are nice, but don't really give a lot of insight into the actual state of the game) is probably also warranted, and would go a long ways to calming everyone down.

Of course, I wouldn't complain if Squad announced that the deadlines have been lifted and that there will be another few alphas with more features (like more planets and a meaningful career mode), followed by several proper beta releases and then finally a solid 1.0 that puts other developers to shame.

> 
> Squad still hasn't really done anything to clear up the FUD around this whole issue, and their relative silence on this issue is what keeps feeding the speculation.

That's par for the course with Squad, though; they've never been very good at communicating outside of PR and marketing material, and they're a bit gun-shy after the DLC incident. Shame, really.

"The community" has already purchased the game (or at least, I expect so), so Squad needs other people to pay for the game. Keeping former buyers happy is a good thing for any company, but let's be real here, it doesn't beat the cha-ching of new customers which should come when the game stops being early access or beta. And as for bugs, sadly, it's becoming common place for games to be launched bugged and getting fixed later on. It's not a good thing, but it happens and customers keep rewarding that business model.

And ultimately, a company doesn't have to share it's financial records with their customers, at least not when you're a private company selling to the general public. If Squad decided to go public, then they'll need to disclose that information in Mexico's stock exchange, according to Mexican laws and regulations. But as long as they aren't a public company, their financial hurdles (or the lack of them) it's their issue.
